mn141:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
mn141:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.

mn141:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn141:2.1.pli: “Tathāgatena, bhikkhave, arahatā sammāsambuddhena bārāṇasiyaṃ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ, yadidaṃ—
mn141:2.1.eng: “Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.
mn141:2.1.comm: This is in reference to the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta, the so-called First Sermon (SN 56.11), for which the current discourse serves as a canonical commentary.

mn141:2.2.pli: catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ.
mn141:2.2.eng: It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.

mn141:3.1.pli: Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ, dukkhasamudayassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ, dukkhanirodhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ.
mn141:3.1.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
mn141:3.1.comm: The four noble truths are sometimes said to be like a doctor who identifies the illness, discerns its cause, understands the recovery, and administers the cure until the patient is restored to health (SA 389 at T ii 105a25; SA-2 254 at T ii 462c10). This analogy is not found in the Pali canon.

mn141:4.1.pli: Tathāgatena, bhikkhave, arahatā sammāsambuddhena bārāṇasiyaṃ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ, yadidaṃ—
mn141:4.1.eng: Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

mn141:4.2.pli: imesaṃ catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ.
mn141:4.2.eng: It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.

mn141:5.1.eng: Mendicants, you should cultivate friendship with Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

mn141:5.2.eng: You should associate with Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

mn141:5.3.eng: They’re astute, and they support their spiritual companions.

mn141:5.4.eng: Sāriputta is like one who gives birth,
mn141:5.4.comm: To extol his leading students, the Buddha recalls his own upbringing, born of Māyā and raised by Mahāpajāpatī (who appears in the next discourse). Nonetheless, janetā is a masculine noun and it would be misleading to translate it as “mother”. Both mother and father “give birth” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.4.14; the creator is male at 1.4.4).

mn141:5.5.eng: while Moggallāna is like one who raises the child.
mn141:5.5.comm: Āpādetā is a causative agent noun from ā + √pad in the sense “one who raises”. Again, both mother and father are “raisers” (āpādakā) of the child (AN 4.63:2.6).

mn141:5.6.pli: Sāriputto, bhikkhave, sotāpattiphale vineti, moggallāno uttamatthe.
mn141:5.6.eng: Sāriputta guides people to the fruit of stream-entry, Moggallāna to the highest goal.

mn141:5.7.pli: Sāriputto, bhikkhave, pahoti cattāri ariyasaccāni vitthārena ācikkhituṃ desetuṃ paññāpetuṃ paṭṭhapetuṃ vivarituṃ vibhajituṃ uttānīkātun”ti.
mn141:5.7.eng: Sāriputta is able to explain, teach, assert, establish, clarify, analyze, and reveal the four noble truths in detail.”

mn141:6.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn141:6.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
mn141:6.2.eng: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

mn141:7.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto acirapakkantassa bhagavato bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn141:7.1.eng: Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the mendicants,

mn141:7.3.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

mn141:8.1.pli: “Tathāgatena, āvuso, arahatā sammāsambuddhena bārāṇasiyaṃ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ, yadidaṃ—
mn141:8.1.eng: “Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

mn141:8.2.pli: catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ.
mn141:8.2.eng: It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.

mn141:9.1.pli: Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ, dukkhasamudayassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ, dukkhanirodhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṃ.
mn141:9.1.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

mn141:10.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of suffering?

mn141:10.2.pli: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, maraṇampi dukkhaṃ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ; saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
mn141:10.2.eng: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.

mn141:11.1.comm: Here Sāriputta takes the analysis a step further than the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta. This extended analysis of the truths was adopted from here into DN 22:18.4, which further expanded the sections on the second and third noble truths in Abhidhamma style shared with Vb 4. | The definitions of rebirth, old age, and death are standard in dependent origination (SN 12.2:4.2), and are taught by Sāriputta also at MN 9:22.2.

mn141:11.2.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jāti sañjāti okkanti abhinibbatti khandhānaṃ pātubhāvo āyatanānaṃ paṭilābho,
mn141:11.2.eng: The rebirth, inception, conception, regeneration, manifestation of the aggregates, and acquisition of the sense fields of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

mn141:12.2.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jarā jīraṇatā khaṇḍiccaṃ pāliccaṃ valittacatā āyuno saṃhāni indriyānaṃ paripāko,
mn141:12.2.eng: The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

mn141:13.2.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhā tamhā sattanikāyā cuti cavanatā bhedo antaradhānaṃ maccu maraṇaṃ kālaṅkiriyā khandhānaṃ bhedo kaḷevarassa nikkhepo jīvitindriyassupacchedo,
mn141:13.2.eng: The passing away, passing on, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, laying to rest of the corpse, and cutting off of the life faculty of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

mn141:14.2.pli: Yo kho, āvuso, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa soko socanā socitattaṃ antosoko antoparisoko,
mn141:14.2.eng: The sorrow, sorrowing, state of sorrow, inner sorrow, inner deep sorrow in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.

mn141:15.2.pli: Yo kho, āvuso, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa ādevo paridevo ādevanā paridevanā ādevitattaṃ paridevitattaṃ,
mn141:15.2.eng: The wail, lament, wailing, lamenting, state of wailing and lamentation in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.

mn141:16.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, āvuso, kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ kāyikaṃ asātaṃ kāyasamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ,
mn141:16.2.eng: Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.

mn141:17.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, āvuso, cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ cetasikaṃ asātaṃ manosamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ,
mn141:17.2.eng: Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact.

mn141:18.2.pli: Yo kho, āvuso, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa āyāso upāyāso āyāsitattaṃ upāyāsitattaṃ,
mn141:18.2.eng: The stress, distress, state of stress and distress in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.

mn141:19.1.pli: Katamañcāvuso, yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ?
mn141:19.1.eng: And what is ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering’?

mn141:19.2.pli: Jātidhammānaṃ, āvuso, sattānaṃ evaṃ icchā uppajjati:
mn141:19.2.eng: In sentient beings who are liable to be reborn, such a wish arises:

mn141:19.3.pli: ‘aho vata mayaṃ na jātidhammā assāma; na ca vata no jāti āgaccheyyā’ti.
mn141:19.3.eng: ‘Oh, if only we were not liable to be reborn! If only rebirth would not come to us!’

mn141:19.4.eng: But you can’t get that by wishing.

mn141:19.5.eng: This is: ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’

mn141:19.6.eng: In sentient beings who are liable to grow old …

mn141:19.9.eng: experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, such a wish arises:

mn141:19.10.pli: ‘aho vata mayaṃ na sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā assāma; na ca vata no sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā āgaccheyyun’ti.
mn141:19.10.eng: ‘Oh, if only we were not liable to experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress! If only sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress would not come to us!’

mn141:19.11.eng: But you can’t get that by wishing.

mn141:19.12.eng: This is: ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’

mn141:20.1.eng: And what is ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’?
mn141:20.1.comm: The five aggregates sum up the entirety of suffering, since all suffering is experienced within and by means of the aggregates.

mn141:20.2.eng: They are the grasping aggregates that consist of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

mn141:20.3.eng: This is called ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.’

mn141:20.4.eng: This is called the noble truth of suffering.

mn141:21.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering?
mn141:21.1.comm: The second and third noble truths are here analyzed to the same level of depth as the First Sermon, with no further definition of terms. See MN 9:16.2 for notes.

mn141:21.2.pli: Yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṃ—
mn141:21.2.eng: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is,

mn141:21.3.eng: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.

mn141:21.4.eng: This is called the noble truth of the origin of suffering.

mn141:22.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?

mn141:22.2.pli: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo,
mn141:22.2.eng: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.

mn141:22.3.eng: This is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.

mn141:23.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?

mn141:23.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

mn141:23.3.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
mn141:23.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

mn141:24.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, āvuso, dukkhe ñāṇaṃ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ,
mn141:24.2.eng: Knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
mn141:24.2.comm: From here we have the standard definitions of the items of the noble eightfold path (SN 45.8:3.2; compare MN 117). | Ignorance is described in the opposite way (MN 9:64–66.7, SN 12.2:14.2).

mn141:25.2.eng: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.

mn141:26.1.comm: The items of right speech and right action are covered in greater detail under the ten pathways of skilful deeds at MN 41:12.4.

mn141:26.2.pli: Musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī,
mn141:26.2.eng: Refraining from lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and talking nonsense.

mn141:27.2.pli: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī,
mn141:27.2.eng: Refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct.

mn141:28.2.pli: Idhāvuso, ariyasāvako micchāājīvaṃ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappeti,
mn141:28.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple gives up wrong livelihood and earns a living by right livelihood.

mn141:29.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati,
mn141:29.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

mn141:29.3.pli: uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati,
mn141:29.3.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.

mn141:29.4.pli: anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati,
mn141:29.4.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

mn141:29.5.pli: uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati,
mn141:29.5.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

mn141:30.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
mn141:30.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

mn141:30.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

mn141:30.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ,
mn141:30.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

mn141:31.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati,
mn141:31.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn141:31.3.pli: vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati,
mn141:31.3.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn141:31.4.pli: pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe…
mn141:31.4.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

mn141:31.5.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn141:31.7.eng: This is called the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

mn141:32.1.pli: Tathāgatenāvuso, arahatā sammāsambuddhena bārāṇasiyaṃ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ, yadidaṃ—
mn141:32.1.eng: Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

mn141:32.2.pli: imesaṃ catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkamman”ti.
mn141:32.2.eng: It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.”

mn141:32.4.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn141:32.4.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what Sāriputta said.
